docs.snippet: The Supreme Court lifted a travel ban on Pakistan’s former ambassador to the United States on Monday, a sign that the so-called memogate scandal may be losing steam....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court lifted a travel ban on Pakistan's former ambassador to the United States on Monday, a sign that the so-called memogate scandal may be losing steam. The ambassador, Husain Haqqani, right, resigned in November and returned to Islamabad to answer allegations that he sent a memo to Washington asking for help in curbing the Pakistani military in exchange for security policies favorable to the United States. Mr. Haqqani has denied having anything to do with the memo, which was unsigned. He said he intended to travel to United States to join family members there.
docs.abstract: Pakistan's Supreme Court lifts travel ban on Husain Haqqani, former United States ambassador; Haqqani had resigned amid allegations he had sent a memo to Washington asking for help in curbing the Pakistani military in exchange for security policies favorable to the US. Photo (S)

headline.main: Pakistan: Court Lifts Envoy's Travel Ban

docs.snippet: Airplane passengers are going to have to leave their cigarette lighters home, under a policy announced by the Transportation Security Administration....
docs.lead_paragraph: Airplane passengers are going to have to leave their cigarette lighters home, under a policy announced on Monday by the Transportation Security Administration. The ban, which takes effect April 14, will also prohibit lighters inside checked baggage for safety reasons. Passengers will still be allowed to carry matches, at least for now.
docs.abstract: Transportation Security Adm announces airplane cigarette lighter ban; passengers may not carry lighters on board aircraft or check them in luggage, but they can still carry matches (S)

headline.main: Ban on Lighters In Air Travel

docs.snippet: It is hard to deny the value of a free trade in ideas and information across international frontiers. Yet for five years, successive Administrations have resisted lifting restrictions on travel by writers and artists during trade embargoes against...
docs.lead_paragraph: It is hard to deny the value of a free trade in ideas and information across international frontiers. Yet for five years, successive Administrations have resisted lifting restrictions on travel by writers and artists during trade embargoes against countries like North Korea, Vietnam and Cuba. Now the Clinton Administration appears to be playing the same game. It promised to review existing bans in order to fend off a liberalizing amendment put forward by Representative Howard Berman, a California Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee on international operations. But after the review, Cuba was still excluded from any relaxation of travel bans.

headline.main: A Demeaning Travel Ban to Cuba
